newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian domestic grain buying for army very low.
newsitem.headline: Russian domestic grain buying for army very low.

text.p: Russia has a slightly bigger harvest this year but is behind schedule in purchasing grain from domestic farmers, an Agriculture Ministry official said on Tuesday.

Ivan Gridasov, head of the ministry's crop-growing department, told Interfax news agency that state reserves for the army and far-flung towns had only 400,000 tonnes out of a targeted 4.5 million tonnes.
But he said the government had bought 8.2 million tonnes of domestic grain for other uses by the end of November, below last year's 8.7 million tonnes.
Russia's net harvest is expected to weigh in officially at a gross 70 million tonnes or so, above last year's 63.4 million tonnes.
But both figures have probably under-reported actual output by several million tonnes.
Gridasov said the government had bought 4.7 million tonnes of wheat, almost one million tonnes less than a year earlier.
Government rye purchases were up to 1.55 million tonnes against 1.06 million tonnes at this time last year.
Gridasov said elevators held more than three million tonnes of grain, half of which was bread-making wheat, on behalf of farmers who were reluctant to sell at low state prices.
